ASSESSMENT OF PERSONAL EXPOSURES
TO ENVIRONMENTAL TOBACCO SMOKE IN
. BRITISH NONSMOKERS
Keith Phillips, David A. Howard, David Browne, and J. Mark Lewsley
Hazloton Europo, Harrogato, North Yorkshire, HG3 1PY, England
EI 9405-153 M (Received 12 May 1994; accepted 2 July 1994)
Eavironmental Tobscco Smoke (ETS) exposure of 255 nonsmoking subjects was assessed by
several methods. Each subject wore a personal air sampler for 24 h, answered a questionnaire
about air quality and ET'S exposure, and provided saliva samples for cotinine analysis before and
fer the monitoring period. The stedy was conducted in the Leeds and Harrogate areas of northern
England. Median exposure to ETS particles was below the detection limit of 4 μg m'. Median
exposure to nicotine was 0.5 ug m" and median saliva cotinine levels were O.7 ng mL and
0.6 ng mL. for the pre- and post-cotinine samples. Median exposure to particles from all souroes
was 142 ug m'. Approximxtely 80% of subjecis assessed their ETS exposure as none or low. On
average, the home mado tho greatest contribution to ETS exposuro, followed by lelaure, and then
work. Travel war x minor contributor to exposure. Overell, subjocts with a pertner who smoked
were exposed to more ETS than subjects with no partner or & monsmoking partner. However, there
was considerable overiap in the exposures of individusls withia these groups. Where subjects
assessed thelr Bts exposure as none or low, this was genorally supported by the direct measure-
ments of exposure. However, for exposure assessed as moderate or high there was a wids range
in the corresponding direct measurements. Thore was a moderate correlation between exposure
to nicotine and exposure to ETS particles (R-0.66). but poor correlation between nicotine
exposure and saliva cotinine levels (R=0.07 for pre- and R³=0.13 for postcotinine samples).
Overall, ETS made only a small (median 2.5%) comtribution to particles from all sources as
collected by the personal monitor. Exposure to ETS particles did not correlate (R²-O.04) with
exposure to particles from all sources. Out of 327 volunteers recruited as nonsmokers for this
study, 53 (16%) were identified as likely smokers by saliva cotinino lovels or detailed questloning.
ly measured exposure, It is also important to deter-
